text: Numerous archival papers indicate that investors can generate profit by following disciplined trading strategies that exploit the market’s incomplete adjustment for various accounting data. Even assuming efficient markets in which securities are not mispriced, evidence suggests that both individual and professional investors could improve their returns via disciplined trading strategies like market indexing. Yet, investors rarely follow such strategies. We use two experiments to examine factors that we believe affect reliance on trading strategies by affecting whether investors have more confidence in their own judgment or the recommendation of a trading strategy. We find that MBA-student investors deviate from a trading strategy more when the strategy is less accurate (but still more accurate than most well-known trading strategies), when they trade individual securities instead of portfolios, and when they receive positive feedback on trading decisions made prior to learning about the strategy. Thus, investors may lack the discipline to rely on profitable trading strategies, particularly when recent trading success has increased their confidence in their own judgment (as might occur in a sustained bull market like that experienced over the past decade). Our results also suggest ways that individual investors and portfolio managers can increase reliance on profitable trading strategies. 2

text: Numerous archival studies indicate that investors can generate profit by relying on disciplined trading strategies that exploit the market’s incomplete adjustment for various accounting data.1 Even assuming efficient markets in which securities are not mispriced, evidence suggests that both individual and professional investors could improve their returns via disciplined trading strategies like market indexing.2 In this paper, we describe two experiments that examine whether the extent to which investors rely on such disciplined trading strategies depends on factors that affect investors' confidence in their own judgment relative to their confidence in the trading strategy. In experiment 1 we test whether reliance varies with accuracy of the trading strategy; in experiment 2 we test whether reliance varies with perceived accuracy of individual judgment. In both experiments we test whether reliance depends on making trading decisions at the individual-security or portfolio level. This paper integrates research on trading strategies with the literature on decision aids, which has shown in a variety of other accounting tasks that decision-makers often fail to follow an aid’s recommendations, even though recommendations are based on statistical models that perform well in large samples. The paper also contributes to the literature that examines the 1 Such data include recent changes in earnings and prices (e.g., Bernard and Thomas 1990; Chan, Jagadeesh and Lakonishok 1996; Swaminathan and Lee 2000), accounting accruals (Sloan, 1996), or estimates of firms’ intrinsic value derived from analysts' earnings forecasts (Frankel and Lee, 1998). Some researchers argue that apparently successful trading strategies simply reflect misspecification of risk-adjusted return (e.g., Fama 1998). We view a trading strategy as a type of decision aid. The investors buy or sell laboratory securities that are based on archival data. For each security, investors are given the recommendation of a trading program that operationalizes a particular trading strategy, and are told the accuracy of the program. They are also given additional accounting information. Investors are paid according to the profitability of their trading decisions. In experiment 1 we examine the effects of the accuracy of the trading program and the level of aggregation at which investors make trading decisions. We manipulate trading-program accuracy by choosing a trading program (based on DeBondt and Thaler, 1990) that is more accurate for sell recommendations than for buy recommendations. We derive this prediction from the “dual source” model of confidence (Sniezek, Paese and Switzer 1990). The dual-source model asserts that decision-makers assess from case-specific information their confidence for individual decisions (such as the trade of a single stock), which tends to encourage overconfidence, but assess confidence for a group of decisions (such as the creation of a security portfolio) from their knowledge of their general ability, which tends to be relatively more accurate (see, e.g., Sniezek and Buckley 1991). We extend the dual-source model to consider the level of aggregation at which decisions are made about reliance on trading programs (and other decision aids). Results from experiment 1 generally support our predictions. Investors deviate substantially from the program, and these deviations significantly lower their trading profits. Results also indicate an interaction between the accuracy and aggregation effects: investors deviate less from the trading program only when the program is more accurate and when they evaluate portfolios rather than individual securities. Deviations from the trading program are greatest when the program is less accurate. However, even our less-accurate program is more accurate than many well-known anomaly-based trading programs (such as those exploiting post- earnings-announcement drift), which correctly pick only slightly more than 50% of securities. This suggests that investors may lack the discipline to exploit and eliminate persistent market anomalies. Our second experiment examines whether investors’ confidence in their own ability affects reliance by presenting some of our investors with feedback on their performance trading five securities without access to the trading program. Consistent with the “balance of confidence” perspective, investors who learn that they made good trading decisions subsequently rely less heavily on the trading program than investors who learn that they made poor trading decisions, even though no investor receives enough feedback to draw very reliable inferences about their abilities. Consistent with the dual-source model, viewing trades at a portfolio level encourages trading-program reliance when investors lack feedback, and encourages trading- program reliance to a greater extent when investors received negative feedback than when investors received positive feedback. Overall, our results suggest that investors’ reliance on trading strategies could be improved by encouraging decision making at the portfolio level. Our results also shed light on behavioral forces that may keep investors from exploiting known anomalies. Investors’ responses to feedback suggest that past trading success can reduce future performance by increasing investors’ overconfidence. An implication of this finding is that investors may be least likely to exploit known anomalies when a sustained bull market gives them much positive feedback (as has happened over the past decade). Results obtained with MBA students may not always generalize to the professional money managers who are in the best position to make trading decisions and exploit price biases. However, prior research suggests that the judgments of more experienced investors may display even more overconfidence in their own abilities to process information (see, e.g., Yates, McDaniel and Brown, 1991). Thus, professional investors may deviate even more often from trading strategies than do our less-experienced subjects. 4

We extend decision-aid research by examining how investors’ confidence in a trading strategy, relative to their confidence in their own abilities, alters the extent to which they adhere to the strategy. The trading context differs from other decision-making contexts in three important ways, all of which have direct bearing on this process: the choice of trade size, the low accuracy of most trading strategies, and the ability to make decisions on either an individual or portfolio basis. 2.1.2.1 Trade size. Many decision-aid studies ask decision-makers to choose from a small number of options (e.g., accept or reject). An investor’s choice to buy or sell a security is thus similar to the choices in previous research. However, the trading task also involves an additional decision: how many shares to buy or sell. All else equal, theoretical models (e.g., Kyle 1985), experimental research (e.g., Bloomfield, Libby and Nelson, 1996) and anecdotal evidence (e.g., O’Brien, 2000) suggest that investors buy or sell more shares as their confidence increases. The trading context thus provides us with a powerful methodological tool to examine confidence effects. We can also examine differences in trading profit and loss to identify the practical consequences of deviations from a trading strategy. 2.1.2.2 Trading-strategy accuracy. Most trading strategies are relatively inaccurate. For example, consider the widely-known and apparently successful strategy exploiting post-earnings- announcement drift. Most decision-aid studies provide a decision aid’s accuracy as a known constant, and so cannot investigate the effect of aid accuracy on aid reliance. One exception is Powell (1991), who manipulated aid accuracy via deception in the context of selecting from among three choices the winner of the National Baseball League Most Valuable Player (MVP) award. Accuracy had a significant but modest effect on the extent to which participants agreed with the decision aid. Ashton (1990 experiment 3) and E. Davis (1998) found that auditors on average agreed more with the recommendations of aids that appear to be based on more information. We interpret these results as evidence that low decision-aid accuracy reduces decision- makers’ confidence in the aid, relative to their confidence in their own judgment. We predict that investors likewise will rely less on a trading strategy as the strategy's accuracy decreases. 2.1.2.3 Trading-decision aggregation. Investment decisions differ from many other decisions because investors are encouraged to think about each of their investments in the aggregate context of their entire portfolio (Sharpe and Alexander 1990). This contrasts with prior decision-aid research where, because of the nature of the judgments made in most contexts, reliance on decision aids tends to be examined for individual cases. For example, auditors try to calculate appropriate sample size for a particular client (Kachelmeier and Messier 1990) or determine whether they face fraud for a particular client (Boatsman et al. 1997). Bond raters judge the credit-worthiness of a particular firm (Ashton 1990, Whitecotton and Butler 1998, Whitecotton et al, 1998). text: Prior research suggests that investors who make trading decisions by evaluating portfolios are likely to behave quite differently from those who evaluate individual securities, because the overconfidence common in individual judgments is typically reduced when confidence is assessed in the aggregate. For example, a typical overconfidence study in psychology requires participants to answer a large number of quantitative general-knowledge questions, and for each question also asks participants to state bounds of a 90% confidence interval. Compared to actual performance, participants’ confidence intervals are insufficiently wide, indicating overconfidence. Yet, the same participants provide a much more accurate (i.e., lower) confidence assessment when asked aggregate questions like “What is the proportion of correct responses that you provided over the last X questions.”9 One useful explanation for this aggregation effect is the dual source model, introduced by Sniezek et al. (1990). Under the dual source explanation, confidence assessments on a case- by-case basis depend on relatively poor information about the specific case, but aggregate confidence assessments depend on more general factors like prior performance on similar tasks and self-assessed expertise with respect to the topic. Because people’s information about themselves is of generally higher quality than their information about the case, they tend to give more accurate aggregate confidence assessments (Sniezek and Buckley 1991, Treadwell and T. Nelson 1996). text: Investors’ confidence in portfolio decisions is likely to depend on relatively good information on their own (low) abilities, leading to reduced overconfidence and increased reliance on the trading strategy. Therefore, we predict trading-strategy reliance will be greater in the portfolio-trading setting than in the individual-trading setting. 2.2 Method 2.2.1 Trading program, securities and design. To test our predictions, we developed a trading program that allows us to manipulate trading-strategy accuracy while holding constant the basic decision task and information used by the decision aid. The program is based on systematic errors in analysts’ forecasts: analysts who predict large increases in earnings tend to be optimistic, while those who predict large decreases tend to be pessimistic (DeBondt and Thaler, 1990). In order to translate this finding into an implementable trading strategy, we construct 30 securities, each based on a real firm. A security has a value of $2 if the related firm’s actual earnings growth was at least the earnings growth predicted by analysts and $0 if the firm’s actual earnings growth was less than the earnings growth predicted by analysts. The price of this laboratory security is always $1.10 The trading program recommends that investors BUY securities with projected earnings declines and SELL securities with projected earnings growth. Half of the recommendations are SELL, the other half are BUY. SELL recommendations are more accurate (75% correct) than BUY recommendations (55% correct). Thus, trading-program accuracy is manipulated within- subjects via the different accuracy of BUY and SELL recommendations.11 10 Our securities are based on earnings, rather than on stock prices. This approach has the advantage of avoiding noise in responses that might occur if investors believe prices inefficiently reflect information. 11 Manipulating accuracy via BUY v. SELL means that accuracy is confounded with BUY v. SELL. Investors may be somewhat reluctant to sell securities they do not have, regardless of whether or not there are short-selling constraints. However, since we anticipate that investors will follow sell recommendations more than they follow buy recommendations, a reluctance to sell biases away from support for our hypothesis. 11

text: Future research might also examine more carefully the factors that drive our aggregation and feedback effects. Within our experimental design, several forces could lead to an aggregation effect. Our decision-aggregation manipulation always occurred in a particular order: investors first made case-by-case judgments, and then made portfolio judgments. Although the decrease in reliance demonstrated by positive-feedback investors indicates that the aggregation treatment did not uniformly increase reliance by serving as a reminder to follow the trading program, we cannot rule out some effect of order. Also, the portfolio treatment always organized investors’ trading decisions into the 2x2 design created from the trading-program recommendations and their case-by-case decisions. Thus, portfolio effects could have occurred because investors' decisions were more structured rather than because the portfolio approach encourages investors to consider their general ability and weigh that against the trading program’s accuracy. We chose our approach because we consider it likely that practical portfolio approaches would include structure and be used following consideration of security- specific information, but future research might seek to determine the extent to which ordering and structure affect results. Our design also does not allow us to separate the effects of aggregation on investors’ confidence in themselves from its effects on investors’ confidence in the trading program. It is possible that investors were more confident in the program when making decisions at the portfolio level because they focussed more on the probability that the program would produce a gain across all 15 securities, while at the individual-security level they focussed on only the probability that the program produced a profit for that security.
